pros: Great people, great community-depending on your department. If you are a student, it is convenient to work on campus as you can go to class easily. Full time staff receive a tuition benefit, but you are taxed on it as though it is part of your salary. It is a great place to work if you are attending DTS.
cons: The pay is terrible and inconsistent across departments and roles. They clearly value a certain type of person at DTS, and that shows in compensation and who they keep around.

pros: Great people to work with!
cons: Workload at this point and time was sometimes overwhelming.

pros: Management was great. Very organized. Lenient. Flexible. Overall great place to work.
cons: Sometimes things get hectic and projects come in back to back.

pros: Convenient if you live on campus, tuition benefits and ministry time off as full time employee

pros: Lots of laughing! We all had so much fun despite the stress of everyone’s workload. DTS was a fun, happy place to work. Mistakes were very easily forgiven. There was a lot of grace and second chances. My boss was very understanding of traffic making us late or needing a rest day, or time off. Work-life balance AMAZING.
cons: I never got a raise. Underpaid since the beginning. There seemed to be a lot of unnecessary drama between each department, as though everyone was competing to be better or something.

pros: As with any academic institution, a lot depends on what department you work in. Also, as with any school, there is often an iron curtain feel between the faculty and staff. Having worked in a supported role (staff) for six years, I can say it was over all a good experience. Most (not all) people are generally friendly and the work hours are good.
cons:
As I said, a lot depends on which department you work for. My department was great, but it served the rest of the campus, faculty and staff. With any service role you are going to come into some rude people. 

Overall though, it was disappointing to see that the faculty tended to be the rudest, though some were very nice. The faculty are under a lot of pressure at DTS, but many of them have taken an elitist attitude which does not help a ministry environment. 

DTS is a personality-promotion environment. In other words, people are given position and power because they are friends with a leader, or through other political maneuvering. This it how it works: there are many jobs at the school that require skills sets that have little or nothing to do with the skill set the school teaches (theological studies). But, because the school's leadership's skill set is theological studies and teaching, they tend to promote people who have that same skill set, even to positions that have little to nothing to do with that. What DTS has ended up with is an environment that has more respect for people who can politically maneuver themselves (play politics) to positions they might never acquire outside the school. Some of the staff are vastly under-qualified to do their job. Though, I don't expect DTS is any different than other theological schools in this way. 

The compensations, both in salary and benefits, at DTS is poor. The HR department maintains that compensation is competitive, but that dose not mean it is reasonable or even livable.

job_title: Operations Manager At Washington Hall in Dallas, TX
pros: Christian environment, tuition assistance, work on campus. This is a good place to work, especially if you are a student. Full time workers get great tuition assistance, which offsets costs big time.
cons: Low pay. Don'e expect to support a family, unless you get a senior management job. Or, if you like being poor, then by all means...

pros: It was a joy to work with my team members and I loved serving students.
cons: The pay is low for industry standard, but when it is a not for profit organization, that should be expected. The reward of the job also helps make up for the pay.

review_title: Without a doubt, the best working environment an employee could ask for.
pros: Employees that become family, consistent integrity and character of administration, employee benefits
cons: There are none that I can submit.
